citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The licensee failed to have frequent and direct communication with their attending veterinarian (AV) regarding the thin
body condition of one white-tailed yearling deer. Upon inspection, the inspector observed a lean yearling white-tailed deer
with an evident spine, prominent ribs, sharp pin bones, and a small amount of observable fat. This deer contrasted with
the other yearling in the herd, who had an ideal body condition. The licensee does not have a treatment plan approved by
the attending veterinarian for underweight deer and had not contacted the attending veterinarian regarding this deer.
An underweight body condition could indicate an underlying health issue and if left untreated could result in the pain,
distress, additional systemic problems, or death of the animal. Daily observation of all animals is necessary to assess
their health and well-being. If any problems of animal health, behavior, or well-being are noted, they must be conveyed to
the attending veterinarian in a timely and accurate manner to allow for appropriate diagnosis and treatment.
This deer must be evaluated by a licensed veterinarian for an accurate diagnosis and to develop an effective treatment
plan.
To be corrected by: end of Business October 3, 2025. The deer was evaluated by a licensed veterinarian on September
26, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The licensee failed to have frequent and direct communication with their attending veterinarian (AV) regarding the thin 
body condition of one white-tailed yearling deer. Upon inspection, the inspector observed a lean yearling white-tailed deer 
with an evident spine, prominent ribs, sharp pin bones, and a small amount of observable fat. This deer contrasted with 
the other yearling in the herd, who had an ideal body condition. The licensee does not have a treatment plan approved by 
the attending veterinarian for underweight deer and had not contacted the attending veterinarian regarding this deer.  
 
An underweight body condition could indicate an underlying health issue and if left untreated could result in the pain, 
distress, additional systemic problems, or death of the animal. Daily observation of all animals is necessary to assess 
their health and well-being. If any problems of animal health, behavior, or well-being are noted, they must be conveyed to 
the attending veterinarian in a timely and accurate manner to allow for appropriate diagnosis and treatment.  
 
This deer must be evaluated by a licensed veterinarian for an accurate diagnosis and to develop an effective treatment 
plan.  
 
To be corrected by: end of Business October 3, 2025. The deer was evaluated by a licensed veterinarian on September 
26, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
 n
